title: William Addison Dwiggins
content:
The name _sounded_ familiar.

He is the designer of the famous typefaces Caledonia and Metro.

But today I encountered his name in quite another connection.

In junior high school, in the textbooks we used reflecting the "New Math", there was a reference to symbols for "dek" and "el", representing the duodecimal digits having the values of ten and eleven.

As it turned out, it was W. A. Dwiggins, who was also an advocate for the use of base-12 instead of decimal, who invented those symbols. Dek, the symbol for ten, is like a capital X, but with the upper left to lower right bar curling over outwards at the ends. El, the symbol for eleven, is an upside-down 3 (the style with a top like that of the 7).
author: quadibloc

comments.content:
Didn't know that - interesting! WAD was indeed a special person.

hhp

Now best remembered as a type designer, WAD was highly regarded in his day (1880-1956) as a designer and illustrator of books and book jackets, too. He wrote [serious prose](http://web.archive.org/web/20140402132426/http:/www.amazon.com/Layout-advertising-W-A-Dwiggins/dp/B0007DLEIM) and [satire](http://web.archive.org/web/20140402132426/http:/imprint.printmag.com/daily-heller/digital-publishing-worrying-you-read-this/), and in his spare time, he wrote plays which he staged in his garage, with all the parts played by [marionettes](http://web.archive.org/web/20140402132426/http:/arrowstreetlive.com/2011/11/dwiggins-marionettes-at-the-bpl/) that he designed and carved himself.
